textgoal: We can see if a list has no items with the isEmpty function.
We can use the head function to get the first item in a list.
"We can use the tail function to get everything except the head."
We can access every item in a list by using just the head and tail functions.
We can add new items into an old list using the cons function to build a new list. Try building the list below.
Cons adds an element to the head position of a list. Try to build the list below.
Build a the list below starting with an empty list using the cons function.
We can reverse a list using the reverse() function.
We can add a value to the end of a list by using reverse() and cons().
Great! Now that we can add an item to the end of a list, let's wrap that up as a function called addToEnd().
Let's try out the functions you've now seen to reach the goal.
The function count() is the number of items in a list. Don't worry. We'll go over the details one step at a time.
If a list is empty, then there are 0 items. Otherwise, there are more than 0 items.
When the isn't empty, then there's 1 item for the head of the list. Afterward, we also add the number of items in the tail of the list.
Reach the goal using the functions in the toolbox.
Use count function to create numbers and build a List
Build the smallList function to count how many items are smaller than 3.
Using all that you've seen, let's try building our own count function.
We can test a condition on the first item of a list. Let's try that. If the condition is true, return the original list. If false, return only the tail of that list.

board: ['function countCondition(list,cond) { return  _; }','countCondition(_, cond)','countCondition(_, cond)','(_) ? (_) : ((_) ? (_) : (_))','countCondition([0,0,0,3,2], x => x == 0)','countCondition([3,6,8,9],x => x > 5)']
textgoal: We can count an item in a list only when a condition is true too. Let's build that function.
defines: ['function countCondition(list, cond) { isEmpty(list) ? 0 : (cond(head(list))) ? 1 + countCondition(tail(list), cond) : countCondition(tail(list), cond) }']

textgoal: Use the functions on lists to reach the goal.
We can use a filter function that only keeps items that makes a condition true. Check it out!
